newsitem.title: FINLAND: Finland Bank mulls using corp notes in euro action.
newsitem.headline: Finland Bank mulls using corp notes in euro action.

text.p: The Bank of Finland is considering whether the range of intervention material could be broadened in its money market actions in the planned European central bank system in EMU, a central bank official said on Wednesday.

Speaking at an EMU seminar arranged by training institute IIR Finland, Olli-Pekka Lehmussaari, head of the bank's intervention office, said the current plans included two tiers of intervention material.
For tier one material, the same criteria would apply in the whole euro area.
Tier two material would be based on national criteria and with risk carried nationally.
The Bank of Finland currently accepts treasury bills, government bonds and and banks' certificates of deposit including its own CDs.
"These things are very much what we are considering at the moment," Lehmuussaari said in response to a question whether the central bank would accept corporate notes and how it would rate them.

He saw benefits in independent corporate paper credit ratings since the central bank's board may otherwise find itself in a difficult position giving its own subjective assessment of individual companies.
Lehmussaari said no decision had been made, but expected a decision in the near future and added that corporations were anxious to know what the bank's plans are.
He declined to comment on whether any other securities than money market instruments might also be considered.
